title: Live-cell metabolic analysis of oligodendroglia isolated from postnatal mouse brain and spinal cord
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Dissociation of brain and spinal cord
Timing: 2–3 h
This section of the protocol describes dissociation of neonatal mouse brain and spinal cord tissues into single cells using Miltenyi’s Neural Tissue Dissociation Kit (P). We have modified the manufacturer’s protocol https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0001320.PDF[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0001320.PDF] in two major ways. First, the original protocol is for brain tissues from mice ≤ 7 days of age, and we have optimized for up to 18 days of age. Secondly, we have expanded the protocol to include dissociation of spinal cord. We tested different dissociation protocols and found that the one detailed below gave the best cell yields (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1939-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Optimization of enzymatic dissociation of neonatal spinal cords
One P10 spinal cord was dissociated using each condition.
Tissue harvest.
Rapidly decapitate mouse. For mice P10 and older, administer chemical anesthetics prior to decapitation.
Dissect brain.
Place carcass dorsal side up.
Separate and cut away skin going from base of neck to nose.
Cut skull from brainstem to olfactory bulb. Remove skull by pulling away to the sides.
Scoop out brain and place in petri dish with cold PBS.
Dissect spinal cord.
Cut and peel back skin to access spinal column.
Dissect out spinal column by cutting through ribs and freeing entire length of the column.
Starting at the caudal (tail) end of the cord, pinch with blunt ended forceps with wide, serrated tips, and squeeze the cord out by progressively moving the forceps (2 pairs) one over the other until the entire cord comes out of the top of the spinal column.
Place in petri dish with cold PBS.
When all dissections are complete, transfer tissues to empty petri dishes. Pool and work with 3 brains or 3 spinal cords at a time.

Chop up tissues to a paste-like consistency using razor blade (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1939-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Dissociation of brain and spinal cord
(A) Tissues chopped to a paste-like consistency using razor blade. Left shows brain samples, right shows spinal cord samples.
(B) Tubes after tissues have settled on ice for 2 min. Left shows brain samples, right shows spinal cord samples.
(C) Tubes after centrifugation. Left shows brain samples, right shows spinal cord samples.
Note: To avoid small differences in developmental stage, we exclusively used littermates within experiments.
Dissociation using Miltenyi’s Neural Tissue Dissociation Kit (P).
Add 1,950 μL preheated Enzyme mix 1 (50 μL Enzyme P + 1,900 μL Buffer X) to 3 pooled P10 spinal cords. Double the volume for 3 pooled brain samples. Transfer to 15 mL conical tubes.
Incubate 15 min at 37°C. Mix every 2–3 min by inverting tubes.
Add 30 μL Enzyme mix 2 (20 μL Buffer Y + 10 μL Enzyme A) to spinal cord samples. Double the volume for brain samples.
Mix by inverting tubes.
Pipette up and down 10× with 5 mL pipette.
Incubate 10 min at 37°C. Mix every 2–3 min by inverting tubes.
Pipette up and down 10× with 1 mL tip.
Place tubes on ice and let tissues settle for 2 min (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). Transfer supernatant (with cells) to fresh 15 mL conical tube. While transferring, pass through pre-wet 70 μm filter.
Break up remaining tissue pellet by pipetting up and down 10× with 200 μL tip. Transfer (through filter) to conical tube with cells from step 2h.
Bring up to 10 mL with BSA buffer.
Count cells with Trypan blue exclusion. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].
Spin down cells at 400 × g for 5 min and aspirate supernatant to remove enzyme (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Proceed to O4+ cell isolation.

Critical: Working quickly during dissection and dissociation will yield higher numbers of viable cells.
O4+ cell isolation
Timing: 1 h
This section of the protocol describes isolating cells expressing the O4 antigen. We begin with diverse cell types dissociated from mouse brains and spinal cords and end with an enriched population of oligodendroglia that express the O4 cell surface sulfatide. O4 is expressed on late stage oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) after the early markers platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRα) and neural/glial antigen 2 (NG2) are mostly downregulated and continues to be present on pre-myelinating as well as actively myelinating oligodendrocytes (Ornelas et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Sommer and Schachner, 1981[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; Warrington and Pfeiffer, 1992[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]). Isolation efficiency using this protocol is 80%–90% (Khandker et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). We have modified the manufacturer’s protocol https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0002007.PDF[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0002007.PDF] for isolation from spinal cords.
Add 80 μL of BSA buffer/ 5 × 106 cells. If a sample has more than 5 × 106 cells, split into multiple 1.5 mL tubes. This prevents clogging of columns.
Add 10 μL mouse FcR Blocking Reagent to each sample/tube.
Mix well by flicking. Do not vortex. Incubate for 10 min at 4°C.
Add 10 μL of Anti-O4 microbeads to each tube.
Mix well by flicking. Do not vortex. Incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Add 1 mL of BSA buffer to each tube.
Centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate supernatant completely.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL BSA buffer.
During above centrifugation steps, prepare columns.
Separate plungers from MS columns. Put aside plungers for future steps.
Place columns in the magnetic field of OctoMACS Separator. Verify that column is facing the correct way. If incorrect, the column will not be vertically straight.
Prepare columns by rinsing with 500 μL BSA buffer.

Add a pre-wet 30 μm filter to each column.
Apply cell suspension onto column filter. Allow entire cell suspension to enter column before proceeding to wash steps. Discard flow-through containing unlabeled cells.
Wash column 3× with 500 μL BSA buffer. Allow entire wash volume to enter column before proceeding to next wash. Discard unlabeled cells that pass through. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3].
Remove each column from separator and place on collection tube.
Pipette 1 mL BSA buffer into the column.
Immediately flush out O4+ enriched cells by firmly pushing plunger into the column. Keep cells onice.
Count cells with trypan blue exclusion and proceed to downstream analyses.
Note: If greater than 80%–90% isolation efficiency is desired, steps 4–18 may be repeated. This will achieve higher purity of O4+ cells but will yield lower cell numbers.
Note: Isolation efficiency can be determined by flow cytometry to measure the percentage of O4+ cells (Khandker et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
Note: If isolated cells are used for different downstream analysis, verify that presence of BSA and EDTA will not interfere. When using O4+ cells for single-cell RNA sequencing, we centrifuged isolated O4+ cells and resuspended in 0.04% BSA in PBS, with no EDTA. When extracting RNA or protein, we resuspended in appropriate lysis buffer. When performing the Agilent Seahorse Cell Mito Stress Test, we resuspended in Assay buffer as described below.
Agilent Seahorse Cell Mito Stress Test
Timing: 4–5 h

In this step, we will plate the O4+ oligodendroglia isolated above and perform live cell metabolic measurements. The Seahorse Mitochondrial Stress Test evaluates mitochondrial function by measuring oxygen consumption rate (OCR), an indicator of mitochondrial respiration. During the assay, modulators of respiration are added to cells through injection ports, which provides a detailed understanding of cell energetics. Extracellular acidification rate (ECAR), an indicator of glycolysis, is also measured. However, for a complete analysis of energy production through glycolysis, the Seahorse Glycolytic Rate Assay Kit should be used.
We have optimized the manufacturer’s protocol https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/XF_Cell_Mito_Stress_Test_Kit_User_Guide.pdf[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/XF_Cell_Mito_Stress_Test_Kit_User_Guide.pdf] specifically for isolated primary oligodendroglia. This included optimization of cell number (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 4B) and FCCP concentration (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Prepare cartridge by removing water from wells and adding pre-warmed calibrant. Do this 45–60 min before running assay.
Prepare Seahorse plate.
Remove PDL from plate.
Wash 1× with sterile water.
Remove water completely and allow to dry before plating cells.
Plate cells.
Isolate and count O4+ cells as described above.
Centrifuge cells at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate supernatant completely.
Resuspend in 540 μL pre-warmed assay media such that there are 40,000 cells/180 μL.
Add 180 μL of assay medium only (no cells) to wells A and H. These are background correction wells.
Add 180 μL of cell suspension (40,000 cells) to remaining wells B-G.
Centrifuge plate for 1 min at 400 × g. This will ensure that cells quickly settle to the bottom of the wells.
Place cell plate in non-CO2 37°C incubator while completing steps 3–7 below.
Prepare stock compounds.
Oligomycin: Add 252 μL assay medium to make 50 μM solution.
FCCP: Add 288 μL assay medium to make 50 μM solution.
Rotenone / Antimycin A: Add 216 μL assay medium to make 25 μM solution.

Pipette each compound up and down 20× to solubilize.
Prepare working solutions of compounds for loading in sensor cartridge by following Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. For example, add 60 μL of 50 μM oligomycin stock solution to 240 μL of assay media. After addition to cell plate, this will result in a final concentration of 1 μM.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1939_3.csv
Load Sensor Cartridge with compounds by following Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. When dispensing compounds into ports, orient the pipette tips at a very slight angle and dispense towards the side wall or corner of the port. Do not push tips completely into the port holes.
Port A: Oligomycin.
Port B: FCCP.
Port C: Rotenone/antimycin A.
Port D: 20 μL of assay medium or PBS. This port can also be used to test the metabolic effects of an additional drug. If the port is not used for an experimental compound, it cannot be left empty and must be filled with media or buffer in order for all compounds to be dispensed.
On the Seahorse XF Mini Analyzer, select XF Cell Mito Stress Test on the Templates window. You can add information about each experimental group on the Plate map tab.
For the protocol described here we kept the default parameters for Cell Mito Stress Test (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). To verify, check that the parameters on the Protocol tab are as follows:

For each stage (Baseline, Oligomycin, FCCP, Rotenone/Antimycin A), there are 3 cycles, 3 mixes, 0 Wait, and 3 Measurements.
For each stage (Baseline, Oligomycin, FCCP, Rotenone/Antimycin A), there are 3 cycles, 3 mixes, 0 Wait, and 3 Measurements.

Start equilibration of Seahorse XF Mini Analyzer by touching “Start Run”. Load the cartridge (hydrated and loaded with compounds) onto the tray when prompted. Ensure the cartridge fits properly, the lid is removed from the cartridge, and the direction of the cartridge matches the image on the screen. Analyzer will complete equilibration in 20 min, then pause until cell plate is loaded.
Note: We allow the Seahorse XF Mini Analyzer to always remain powered on. If not, switch on Analyzer before beginning animal dissections. Before beginning assay, ensure that the temperature reading is at 37°C.
Run the Seahorse XF Cell Mito Stress Test.
Touch “Continue” when you are ready to load your plate.
The XF Mini Analyzer tray will open and present the utility plate.
Remove the utility plate and load the cell plate. Ensure the lid is removed from the cell plate before loading onto the Analyzer tray.
The assay takes about 1.5 h to run. Once the assay is complete, touch Eject to retrieve the sensor cartridge and cell plate. The cell plate can then be used for normalization. This step is critical when working with experimental oligodendroglia which may have different cell viabilities. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5], 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7], 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9].
Gently remove media without disturbing cells.
Add 50 μL of RIPA lysis buffer with Halt protease/phosphatase inhibitor cocktail into each well.
Pipette up and down 5× to lyse and mix.
Measure total protein/well using standard protein measurement protocols.
Use total protein measurement to normalize results in Wave as described below.
Pause point: Protein measurement in step 9 can be performed immediately, or the plate can be stored at −80°C after addition of RIPA lysis buffer and analyzed on a later day.
